children.text: Statistics and probability
Understanding chance

dcterms_description.literal: Sub-element descriptive text

children.text: UnC1
Describing chance
describes everyday occurrences that involve chance

dcterms_description.literal: describes everyday occurrences that involve chance

children.text: makes predictions on the likelihood of simple, everyday occurrences as to it will or won�t, might or might not happen (e.g. I might be able to come and play at your house today; next year I will be � years old; my tower might not fall down)

dcterms_description.literal: makes predictions on the likelihood of simple, everyday occurrences as to it will or won�t, might or might not happen (e.g. I might be able to come and play at your house today; next year I will be � years old; my tower might not fall down)

children.text: UnC2
Comparing chance

describes and orders the likelihood of events in non-quantitative terms such as certain, likely, highly likely, unlikely, impossible (e.g. if there are more blue than red marbles in a bag, blue is more likely to be selected; I am certain that I won�t win the competition because I didn�t enter)

dcterms_description.literal: describes and orders the likelihood of events in non-quantitative terms such as certain, likely, highly likely, unlikely, impossible (e.g. if there are more blue than red marbles in a bag, blue is more likely to be selected; I am certain that I won�t win the competition because I didn�t enter)

dcterms_description.literal: records outcomes of chance experiments in tables and charts

dcterms_description.literal: demonstrates that outcomes of chance experiments may differ from expected results (e.g. we will not get the same results every time we roll a dice)

children.text: UnC3
Fairness
identifies all possible outcomes of one-step experiments and records outcomes in tables and charts

dcterms_description.literal: identifies all possible outcomes of one-step experiments and records outcomes in tables and charts

children.text: explains why outcomes of chance experiments may differ from expected results (e.g. just because there are six numbers on a dice doesn�t mean you are going to roll a 6 every six rolls, you may not roll a 6 in the entire game)

dcterms_description.literal: explains why outcomes of chance experiments may differ from expected results (e.g. just because there are six numbers on a dice doesn�t mean you are going to roll a 6 every six rolls, you may not roll a 6 in the entire game)

dcterms_description.literal: explains that the probabilities of all chance events are either �impossible�, �certain to happen� or lie somewhere in between

dcterms_description.literal: identifies events where the chance of one event occurring will not affect the occurrence of the other (e.g. if a coin is tossed and heads have come up seven times in a row, it is still equally likely that the next toss will be either a head or a tail)

dcterms_description.literal: expresses the theoretical probability of an event as the number of ways an event can happen out of the total number of possibilities

dcterms_description.literal: identifies a range of chance events that have a probability from 0 � 1 (e.g. you have zero probability of rolling a 7 with one roll of a standard 6-sided dice; the probability that tomorrow is Wednesday given today is Tuesday is 1)

dcterms_description.literal: describes probabilities as fractions of one (e.g. the probability of an even number when rolling a dice is 3/6 )

dcterms_description.literal: expresses probabilities as fractions, decimals, percentages and ratios recognising that all probabilities lie on a measurement scale of 0 to 1 (e.g. uses numerical representations such as 75% chance of rain or 4 out 5 people liked the story; explains why you can�t have a probability less than zero)

children.text: UnC5

dcterms_description.literal: determines the probability of compound events and explains why some results have a higher probability than others (e.g. tossing two coins)

Recognising bias
applies an understanding of distributions to evaluate claims based on data (e.g. the predictive accuracy of a sample depends on both the size of a sample and how well it represents the population)
